title: 115_hr4021
content: The Act titled "Leveraging Performance-Based Transportation Services Act of 2017" provides funding for capital projects of leveraged systems. The Leveraging Performance-Based Transportation Services Act of 2017 allows leveraged systems to directly report public transportation data to the National Transit Database. Leveraged systems must also notify designated recipients and metropolitan planning organizations of their submissions. The Leveraging Performance-Based Transportation Services Act of 2017 allows transportation services, whether public or private, to recover operating costs through fare revenue or payments, meet Federal Transit Administration requirements, and not negatively impact other public transportation services. The owner or operator of a leveraged system must enter into an agreement ensuring that at least 90 percent of additional amounts will be used for capital expenditures to expand public transportation services in the designated geographic area. The Leveraging Performance-Based Transportation Services Act of 2017 allows transportation services to recover operating costs through fare revenue or payments, meet Federal Transit Administration requirements, and not negatively impact other public transportation services. Section 5315 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to include leveraging transit services for calculating apportionments for capital payments under sections 5307, 5311, and 5339 based on data submitted to the National Transit Database. During a 30-day period, the owner or operator of a leveraged system must submit data to the National Transit Database, and if the service provided directly competes with the designated recipient's service or has a projected ridership reduction of more than 3 percent, local consent is required. The metropolitan planning organization can object to the use of funds or data for expanded public transportation services if they do not meet requirements or if the owner/operator has not complied with regulations. The Secretary must consider objections from metropolitan planning organizations regarding the use of funds for public transportation services that do not meet requirements. The subsection clarifies that designated recipients cannot control leveraged system services and funds must be used in accordance with regulations.
